repository.corpname: NYU Abu Dhabi, Archives and Special Collections

did.unittitle: Berj Aprahamian photograph collection

physdesc.extent: housed in 14 folders in one box, 0.20 linear feet

did.abstract: Color photographic slides and prints, containing scenes in the city and emirate of Abu Dhabi, that depict scenery, prominent buildings, and the construction of the city's infrastructure, including the first seawall and Corniche, dating chiefly from the late 1960s.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for use in the Reading Room of the Archives and Special Collections department of the NYU Abu Dhabi Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into two series, according to format: slides and prints. Within those, the slides are arranged in roughly chronological order (where dates are present), while the prints are arranged in categories by topic, using descriptive terms and groupings either devised by the creator of the collection, or adapted from those by the processing archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Berj Aprahamian was born in Jerusalem in 1931, where his family lived in the Armenian Quarter. As a child he attended Armenian elementary schools, but his secondary schooling was interrupted due to the Arab-Israeli war of 1947, when Jerusalem was partitioned and he could no longer reach his school. Although he eventually completed his secondary schooling, this forced absence led him to work as a temporary accounting clerk with the British authorities in Palestine. His brother later found him a position as an accountant with a construction firm in Iraq, and working in this environment exposed him to the work of engineers, a field that he developed an interest in. He began studying engineering at Aleppo College in Syria, but after his first year there, he transferred to Roberts College in Istanbul, where he completed his bachelor's degree in Civil Engineering in 1957.

Following his graduation, he returned to Iraq, working with Shaheen and Janabi Contractors as an assistant resident engineer in Kirkuk, but moved to Kuwait in 1958, where he was employed by that country's Ministry of Public Works. In October 1966 he moved to Abu Dhabi, in the Trucial States, where he joined the British construction firm Arabicon. One of the early projects he worked on was the construction of Abu Dhabi's first seawall along what is now that city's Corniche. Aprahamian accompanied the Emirate's ruler, Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan al Nahyan, when the latter attended the ribbon cutting for this project in June 1967, explaining to him the work of dredging, land reclamation, and the sheet piling necessary to build this structure. In 1969 Aprahamian joined the firm of Brook and Khalfan, eventually rising to the level of General Manager, and supervising a variety of infrastructure projects in the city and emirate of Abu Dhabi, ranging from highway construction to the building of the breakwater in 1973, a structure that has led to the development of the Marina district of Abu Dhabi. In 1984 he became a partner in the firm of Spectrum Engineering Consultants in Abu Dhabi.

A year after his arrival in Abu Dhabi, Aprahamian's wife, Suzanne, joined him there, and they raised their two daughters in Abu Dhabi. Aprahamian became an active member of the city's growing Armenian community, where he was instrumental in efforts to establish an Armenian school in the 1970s and later the design and construction of the Armenian Embassy in 2007. He was later active in the Armenian Cultural Association, serving as its honorary chair from 1992 until the dissolution of that group in 2010.

In 2018, at the urging of Sheikh Nahyan bin Mubarak al Nahyan, Aprahamian published a selection of his early photographs of Abu Dhabi in a book dedicated to Sheikh Zayed, and titled "A Tribute with Love : in Memory of Sheikh Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan," in which Sheikh Nahyan provided the foreword.
Berj Aprahamian died at his home in Abu Dhabi on 18 November 2025.

[Source: adapted from the article "The Legacy of Berj Aprahamian," by Hrach Kalsahakian," published February 6, 2024 on the website "Azad-Hye," https://www.azad-hye.com/the-legacy-of-berj-aprahamian/, accessed July 2025, as well as information from family members.]

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The photographic slides in the collection were originally received in a series of small boxes, with some of images being housed in their original cardboard frames, which contained stamped dates that identified when the photographs were originally developed. However, the majority of the images had subsequently been rehoused in plastic frames, some of which contained dates that were later added by the creator of the collection, while others had no dates. Therefore, the dates for many of the groups of images are somewhat tentative. The photographic prints were later produced from these same slides (as well as others not present in this collection), and were grouped and labeled by their creator in large format envelopes. This system of grouping and organizing the photographic prints have been retained, and while the original envelopes have been replaced by acid-free folders, the labels on those envelopes used by the creator of the collection have been trimmed and retained with the images they represent. The collection was processed by Brad Bauer, September - December 2025.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The Berj Aprahamian collection consists of color photographic slides and prints, containing scenes of the city and emirate of Abu Dhabi that depict scenery, prominent buildings, and the construction of the city's infrastructure, including the first seawall and Corniche, dating chiefly from the late 1960s.

The earliest images date from November and December 1966, just a couple of months after Aprahamian's arrival in Abu Dhabi, while the bulk of the images appeared to have been captured between early 1967 and late 1968. The subject matter of his photographs includes scenes of daily life in the city of Abu Dhabi during this period, as well as images more directly related to his work as a civil engineer on projects related to the drive to modernize the city's infrastructure under the rule of Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan. Related to this latter area are images of newly constructed roads, the laying of pipelines, the demolition of older buildings in the center of town, and most notably, the construction of the first seawall along the city's waterfront, including photographs of the work as it progressed, as well as a ceremony at the inauguration of this project, at which Sheikh Zayed was present, in June 1967. The city's changing coastline is a frequent theme in these photographs, with images showing the buildings along the waterfront from various vantage points, goods being unloaded from boats docked at the city's first jetty and port, the effects of coastal flooding, and images of the city as seen from offshore, taken during an engineering survey.

As a new arrival, Aprahamian was also interested in the daily lives of the city's inhabitants and the general surroundings, and documented many different facets of Abu Dhabi, including the old central market (or souq), the city's main street (corresponding roughly with modern-day Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Road), local inhabitants, and in August 1967, the first Accession Day parade, marking the anniversary of Sheikh Zayed's accession as ruler of the Emirate of Abu Dhabi. Also depicted are notable landmarks, such as the first airport terminal and airstrip, used by Gulf Airways (at the site of present-day Al Bateen Executive Airport), the dedication of the Al Khubairat School, which both of Aprahamian's daughters attended, and the first Christian churches in the city. Both the school and the churches were located adjacent to the coastal road that would later be known as the Corniche, but were subsequently moved inland, to the Mushrif district, in the 1980s.

While most of this collection documents the city of Abu Dhabi, a smaller number of images from this period also show portions of the city of Al-'Ain and nearby landscape, including Jebel Hafit, as well as a trip to the emirate of 'Ajman.

The photographs in this collection were initially developed as color photographic slides, many of which were later reproduced as large format photographic prints. As a result, many of the prints duplicate the content of the slides, however, not all of them do.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright to the images in this collection were transferred by the creator to the NYU Abu Dhabi Library at the time of its acquisition. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the NYU Abu Dhabi Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Berj Aprahamian photograph collection; MC.157; box number; folder number or item identifier; Archives and Special Collections, New York University Abu Dhabi Library.
